results.headline: Breaking the Chains of Chinese Feudalism
results.summary_short: A patriotic epic about the Chinese struggle to shake off imperial rule, “1911” is also Jackie Chan’s 100th film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1911

results.headline: Putting Justice Under a Microscope
results.summary_short: “Incendiary” is a documentary about the case of Cameron Todd Willingham, executed by Texas — unjustly, some contend — for the murder of his children by arson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Incendiary: The Willingham Case

results.headline: A Black Rock Band Struggling in a White Milieu
results.summary_short: “Everyday Sunshine,” directed by Lev Anderson and Chris Metzler, recounts the rise and fall of the Los Angeles ska-punk rockers Fishbone.
results.display_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone

results.headline: A Pair of Adolescent Outcasts Hit the Road in Search of Freedom and a Father
results.summary_short: Juno Temple is the title character in a tale about an Oklahoma teenager who embarks on a journey with a high school friend.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dirty Girl

results.headline: One Butch Cassidy Myth Is Replaced by Another
results.summary_short: Mateo Gil’s western, “Blackthorn,” imagines that Butch Cassidy didn’t die in a hail of bullets and instead survived and lived till a ripe old age in Bolivia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blackthorn

results.headline: Cold and White: Immigrants’ Landscape
results.summary_short: “The Nine Muses,” by the British director John Akomfrah, documents in severe winter landscapes the English immigrant experience in the decades after World War II.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nine Muses

results.headline: Back at Home, a Marine Must Battle His Injuries
results.summary_short: “Hell and Back Again,” a documentary by Danfung Dennis, follows Sgt. Nathan Harris, a Marine recovering from a shattered hip and leg.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hell and Back Again

results.headline: Fathers Who Tend to Their Flocks
results.summary_short: “Courageous” is about a Georgia police officer whose job exposes him to social decay and spiritual desolation wrought by fatherless homes, strengthening his devotion to conservative family values.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Courageous

results.headline: Moving Out of New York Is Just a Bad Idea
results.summary_short: In “Dream House,” Rachel Weisz and Daniel Craig meet with odd neighbors and violence in their new home.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dream House

results.headline: A Splintering Psyche or Omens of Disaster?
results.summary_short: “Take Shelter” is a quiet, relentless exploration of the latent (and not so latent) terrors that bedevil contemporary American life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take Shelter

results.headline: A Tale of Russia Haunted by Ghosts and the Living Dead
results.summary_short: “My Joy,” directed by Sergei Loznitsa, creates an air of dread that instantly settles around a young truck driver.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Joy

results.headline: Stay Away From Those Creepy Locals
results.summary_short: A little misunderstanding results in a lot of comical gore in Eli Craig’s feature debut, “Tucker and Dale vs. Evil.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tucker and Dale vs. Evil

results.headline: Rising From the Streets, a Band and Spirits
results.summary_short: The documentary “Benda Bilili!” tells the story of a band, most of whose members are disabled from polio, that rose from poverty in Congo to become an international sensation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Benda Bilili!

results.headline: Mining Past Boyfriends for Husband Material (You Never Know)
results.summary_short: As a woman in her 30s approaches “the number” (of sexual partners, which will make her unmarriageable), she takes a look back at her boyfriends.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What's Your Number?

results.headline: What’s a Teacher Worth?
results.summary_short: The documentary “American Teacher” is a heartfelt, bittersweet portrait of several teachers as they decide whether to stay in the low-paying profession.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Teacher

results.headline: An Ill-Fated Journey Into Cambodia
results.summary_short: “The Road to Freedom” stars Joshua Fredric Smith as Errol Flynn’s son, Sean, a photojournalist who disappeared in Cambodia during the Vietnam War.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Road to Freedom

results.headline: Her Mom, Her Dad and Some Former Friends
results.summary_short: The documentary “Sarah Palin: You Betcha!” takes a look at the former governor of Alaska.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sarah Palin: You Betcha!

results.headline: A Teenager and a Poem in the Post-9/11 World
results.summary_short: Kenneth Lonergan’s “Margaret” follows the title character, played by Anna Paquin, using a poem by Gerard Manley Hopkins, “Spring and Fall.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Margaret

results.headline: Violent Revenge, No Guns Required
results.summary_short: In Guy Moshe’s “Bunraku,” Josh Hartnett plays a drifter seeking revenge against a kingpin in a postapocalyptic dystopia.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bunraku

results.headline: He Sure Looks a Lot Like That Singer
results.summary_short: Goh Nakamura plays what must be a duller version of himself in “Surrogate Valentine.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surrogate Valentine
